column12: there are several risks and ethical concerns associated with using robots in healthcare. One major concern is patient safety: if a robot malfunctions or misinterprets a movement
column13: it could accidentally harm the patient during lifting or transfer. Another issue is privacy
column14: since these robots often use sensors and cameras that collect sensitive health data. Ensuring that this information is securely stored and used responsibly is essential.";"First
column15: patient safety and dignity must always come first. Robots should be designed to handle patients gently and securely
column16: respecting their comfort
column17: privacy
column18: and autonomy. Informed consent is also critical

column20: what data it collects
column21: and how it will be used in their care.

column1: Second

column3: cameras
column4: or AI systems that record sensitive health information
column5: so developers must ensure strict data encryption and compliance with healthcare privacy regulations.

column1: Third
column2: equity and accessibility should be addressed. The technology should not only be available to well-funded hospitals but also accessible to smaller facilities and diverse patient populations.

column1: Lastly

Why I'd hesitate The geriatric patients are the wild card many already feel disoriented powerless or scared. column1: Decreased Physical Strain: It considerably lowers the risk of injury and physical strain for medical personnel.  Moving and assisting patients—particularly young children learning to walk or people with restricted mobility—is a demanding task that increases the risk of musculoskeletal injuries and caregiver burnout.  The heavy lifting and support are handled by the robot. Real-time
column2: objective data on the child's posture
column3: balance
column4: and development ($e.g.
column5: $ force exerted
column6: range of motion) can be gathered by the integrated sensors.  Instead of depending only on observational assessment
column7: this data enables therapists to more effectively customize the rehabilitation plan.";"Yes
column8: I see a number of dangers and moral dilemmas:

column1: Risk of Malfunction/Injury: A sudden movement or loss of support could result from a technical malfunction or sensor misreading
column2: which could cause the child to fall or sustain injuries.  The safety procedures must be very strong because a child user is vulnerable.

column1: Depersonalization of Care: Although the robot helps with the physical task
column2: there is a chance that it will diminish the quantity or quality of crucial human interaction—the support
column3: encouragement
column4: and expert therapeutic touch that a human therapist offers.

column1: Data privacy: The robot gathers private medical and physical performance information.  One of the main concerns is making sure that this data is transmitted
column2: stored
column3: and complies with privacy laws (like HIPAA/GDPR).";"The following ethical concerns are crucial from a professional perspective:

column1: Putting Human Interaction (The ""Care"" Element) First:  The robot must be created and used as a supplement to the expert human therapist
column2: not as a replacement.  Making sure the robot completes the task while the therapist maintains complete accountability for the therapeutic plan and the relationship is the ethical imperative.

column1: Assent and Informed Consent: Since the patient is a minor
column2: getting the parents' genuine informed consent is crucial.  In order to ensure that the child understands the process and is not being forced to use a potentially frightening machine
column3: the development team must also think about how to get assent (willing participation) from the child.

column1: Accountability: Is the manufacturer
column2: the hospital
column3: the managing therapist
column4: or the robot's programmer legally and morally liable if a system malfunctions and a child is hurt?  Prior to implementation
column5: it is necessary to establish clear lines of accountability.

column1: Equity and Access: Children from various socioeconomic backgrounds may not have equal access to cutting-edge rehabilitation due to the high cost of such sophisticated robotic systems
column2: which may limit their availability to well-funded facilities.";6;6;6;6;6;6;6;6;4;4;4;4;6;6;6;5;5;5;5;5;5;"I hereby confirm that I have read and understood the participation information described above and that I agree to th...";"70";"Female";"more than 20 years";"United States of America";5;23;64;5;9;11;261;129;70;140;26;267;127;33;280;25;99;261;33;85;9;521;117;41;353;12;37;1857;NA;2025-12-12 14:13:59;NA;TRUE;FALSE;25;25;0;0;0.69

column1: 151;672;NA;NA;"qnr2";"interview";2025-12-12 15:10:55;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;NA;7;7;4;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"I think this robot could be very useful in delivering medications to nurses and rooms.";"Like many technologies the risk could be a malfunction or hack. If the robot malfunctioned it could deliver the wrong medication to the wrong patient. This robot could also be at risk of a hack which could result in stolen medications and patient information.";"A human would have to ensure that the correct medicines were being delivered so that a medication error did not occur. Also the robot would need to be equiped with the right security to make sure patient privacy was not at risk or medication was not stolen.";7;7;7;4;6;4;4;5;5;6;4;6;4;4;4;5;5;5;5;5;3;5;7;7;4;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"I think this robot is an excellent idea. It would help to preserve the dignity of the patient and also protect the caregivers from injury. As long as a human would be overseeing the entire process that could help mitigate that risk. This robot reminds me of other technology that helps with lifting and moving patients such as lifts and winches.";"I don't see a particular ethical issue. As long as the robot was safely maintained and operated to assure patient safety.";7;7;7;4;7;4;4;6;4;6;4;6;4;4;4;5;5;5;5;4;5;6;6;3;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"I think this robot is similar to current vital sign machines that monitor patients. column2: such as the human body form and facial expressions
column3: are necessary. I think it would be better without these characteristics.";"I think because of the human characteristics
column4: there would be a risk of vulnerable patients (such as children and elderly) becoming overly fond or attached to these machines. Is there also a risk of the robots records being hacked or compromised? column68: and compassionate care.";7;6;7;6;5;6;7;6;5;6;6;5;7;6;7;4;4;3;4;5;5;6;7;2;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"I would accept the use of a robot in caregiving when it clearly assists with supportive or operational tasks—such as monitoring vital signs
column72: because these uses can improve efficiency and reduce physical and cognitive strain on human caregivers. I would be more reluctant to accept the robot in roles that involve emotional care
column75: such as providing comfort during distress
column77: or supporting patients at the end of life. In those situations
column78: I expect care to be grounded in human empathy
column81: which technology cannot fully replicate.";"One major concern is the potential loss of human connection if robots are used too extensively
column82: leading patients to feel isolated or treated as tasks rather than people. There is also a risk of over-reliance on the robot’s outputs
column83: which could reduce critical thinking or vigilance among staff. Privacy and data security are significant issues
column84: especially if the robot continuously collects sensitive health or behavioral data. Additionally
column85: patients may feel they have limited choice in accepting robotic care
column86: raising concerns about informed consent and autonomy.";"From a professional standpoint
column87: it is essential to ensure clear accountability—humans and institutions must remain responsible for decisions and outcomes
column88: even when robots are involved. Transparency about the robot’s capabilities
column90: and decision-making processes is crucial for trust. Equity should also be considered so that robots do not become a justification for lower-quality
column91: less human care in under-resourced settings. Finally
column92: ethical implementation should prioritize human dignity by ensuring that robots augment caregiving work while preserving the central role of human relationships in healthcare.";6;7;6;5;7;6;7;6;5;6;7;6;7;6;6;4;5;3;4;5;5;"I hereby confirm that I have read and understood the participation information described above and that I agree to th...";"24";"Male";"1-5 years";"United States Of America";6;2;4;2;1;93;106;158;8;85;3;96;499;5;63;18;73;24;6;46;5;64;38;6;45;1;17;1026;NA;2025-12-12 16:19:08;NA;TRUE;FALSE;25;25;0;0;1.87

I see no ethical problems.";6;6;6;4;7;3;3;5;5;5;5;5;6;6;6;5;5;5;5;5;5;5;4;4;2;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"Transferring patients is back breaking work and it would be great to have a robot to assist with this part of nursing. I have transferred many patients who are not as steady as the model in the video.  Scared patients tend to feel very insecure during the transfer process.  I think these patients would not transfer well with this robot.";"The risk is that the patient would not be cooperative and would get hurt.

column1: ;I don't see any ethical issues with this robot.";7;5;5;1;7;4;3;6;6;7;7;7;7;7;7;5;5;5;5;5;5;5;7;7;4;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"I accept this robot because it makes the job of the human much safer as it removes the risk of injury.  It should also make the patient safer as it is less likely to fail and drop the patient than a human.";"The only risk/concern I see if injury to the patient should something go wrong with the robot.  This is no different than the risk if a human accidently drops a patient
column2: though.";"I don't see any ethical concerns with this robot because it does still require the care giver to direct it.  It is clearly a helpful and effective robot that should protect both the patient and caregiver.";7;2;2;1;7;3;3;7;5;7;7;6;7;7;7;5;5;5;5;5;5;7;7;3;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;TRUE;NA;"I would accept this robot because it could handle the more basic
column3: but still important
column4: tasks and allow the humans to focus on more critical tasks.  It would make the care team more efficient and effective.";"The risks are the same as if a human was taking/monitoring vitals.  The robot could misread or misinterpret the vitals.  It could also upload incorrect data to the patients' charts.";"I think the main ethical issue is that the robot could be intimidating and/or confusing to some patients.  Without a human present to assist

It supports their work and makes the therapy more effective for the patient.";"The only risk I could see is a malfunction during care that could injure the patient.  This risk is not really much different than a human making an error that injures a patient though.";"The most important ethical issue is that the robots are both safe and effective.
